translated: Points of Controversy
The Great Fifty

analyzed: terasama vagga  samāpannā uassāda iti kathā
translated: The thirteenth section🔽The discussion of whether one who has attained experiences enjoyment

analyzed: samāpannaḥ assādeti jhāna nikanti jhāna ārammaṇā ati
translated: Is it the case that one who has attained experiences enjoyment, that the jhāna is the object of the jhāna?
The Invitation Ceremony.
“Is it the case that that jhāna is the object of that jhāna?”
“Is it so that it is not to be said that it is a person who is the same in the past, the future, and the present?” …
“Is it the case that that jhāna is the object of that jhāna?”

original: Āmantā.🔽Tena phassena taṁ phassaṁ phusati, tāya vedanāya taṁ vedanaṁ vedeti, tāya saññāya
analyzed: āmantā  tena phassena tam phassam phusati tāya vedanāya tam vedanam vedeti tāya saññāya
translated: The invitation.🔽He touches that contact with that contact, he experiences that feeling with that feeling, he perceives that perception with that perception,

original: taṁ saññaṁ sañjānāti, tāya cetanāya taṁ cetanaṁ ceteti, tena cittena taṁ cittaṁ cinteti,🔽tena vitakkena taṁ vitakkaṁ vitakketi, tena vicārena taṁ vicāraṁ vicāreti, tāya pītiyā
analyzed: tam saññam sañjānāti tāya cetanāya tam cetanam ceteti tena cittena tam cittam cinteti  tena vitakkena tam vitakkam vitakketi tena vicārena tam vicāram vicāreti tāya pītiyā
translated: “Is it the case that he contacts that contact with that contact, that he feels that feeling with that feeling, that he perceives that perception with that perception, that he resolves that resolve with that resolve, that he cognizes that cognizance with that cognizance,

original: taṁ pītiṁ piyāyati, tāya satiyā taṁ satiṁ sarati, tāya paññāya taṁ paññaṁ pajānātīti?
analyzed: tam pītim piyāyati tāya satiyā tam satim sarati tāya paññāya tam paññam pajānāti iti
translated: that he thinks that thought with that thought, that he investigates that investigation with that investigation, that he enjoys that enjoyment with that enjoyment, that he remembers that memory with that memory, that he understands that understanding with that understanding?”
“Is it so that it is not to be said that it is a person who is the same in the eye sense-sphere and in the eye-consciousness element?” …
“Is it the case that the jhāna is associated with cognizance, and that the jhāna is associated with cognizance?”
“No.”🔽“Is it the case that there are two contacts …
… of two kinds of contact …
Is there a meeting of two kinds of consciousness?
You say “No.” …
Is the unwholesome attainment of jhāna the same as the wholesome attainment of jhāna?
You say “Yes.” …

original: Kusalākusalā sāvajjānavajjā hīnapaṇītā kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgā dhammā sammukhībhāvaṁ āgacchantīti?
analyzed: kusala akusalā sāvajja anavajjāḥ hīna paṇītā kaṇha sukka sappaṭibhāgāḥ dhammā sammukhībhāvam āgacchanti iti
translated: Do wholesome and unwholesome, blameable and blameless, inferior and refined, dark and bright dhammas with their concomitants come into focus?
You say “No.” …

original: Kusalākusalā sāvajjānavajjā hīnapaṇītā kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgā dhammā sammukhībhāvaṁ āgacchantīti?
analyzed: kusala akusalā sāvajja anavajjāḥ hīna paṇītā kaṇha sukka sappaṭibhāgāḥ dhammā sammukhībhāvam āgacchanti iti
translated: Do wholesome and unwholesome, blameable and blameless, inferior and refined, dark and bright dhammas with their concomitants come into focus?
You say “Yes.” …
But hasn’t it been said by the Blessed One:

analyzed: cattāri imāni bhikkhave su vidūra vidūrāni
translated: “Monks, these four things are very far away.
What four?
The sky and the earth,

original: idaṁ paṭhamaṁ suvidūravidūraṁ …pe… tasmā sataṁ dhammo asabbhi ārakā”ti.
analyzed: idam paṭhamam su vidūra vidūram tasmai satam dhammaḥ
translated: This is the first thing that is very far away. … The Dhamma of the good is far from the worthless.”
Is there such a discourse?
You say “Yes.” …

original: “kusalākusalā sāvajjānavajjā hīnapaṇītā kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgā dhammā sammukhībhāvaṁ āgacchantī”ti.
analyzed: kusala akusalā sāvajja anavajjāḥ hīna paṇītā kaṇha sukka sappaṭibhāgāḥ dhammā sammukhībhāvam āgacchanti iti
translated: Well then, you shouldn’t say that wholesome and unwholesome, blameable and blameless, inferior and refined, dark and bright dhammas with their concomitants come into focus.
You shouldn’t say that.

analyzed: samāpannaḥ assādeti jhāna nikanti jhāna ārammaṇā ati
translated: “Does he enjoy it while attaining it? Is the enjoyment the jhāna itself or the object of the jhāna?”
“The latter.”

original: Nanu vuttaṁ bhagavatā—🔽“idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati, so taṁ assādeti taṁ nikāmeti tena ca vittiṁ āpajjati;
analyzed: nanu vuttam bhagavatā  idha bhikkhave bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati saḥ tam assādeti tam nikāmeti tena ca vittim āpajjati
translated: “But has it not been stated by the Blessed One:🔽‘Here, bhikkhus, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the first jhāna, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion. He enjoys it, delights in it, and finds it satisfactory.

analyzed: vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā pe dutiyam jhānam pe  tatiyam jhānam
translated: With the stilling of applied and sustained thought, he enters upon and abides in the second jhāna, which has self-confidence and singleness of mind without applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of concentration. He enjoys it, delights in it, and finds it satisfactory.🔽With the fading away as well of rapture, he abides in equanimity, and mindful and fully aware, still feeling pleasure with the body, he enters upon and abides in the third jhāna, on account of which noble ones announce: “He has a pleasant abiding who has equanimity and is mindful.” He enjoys it, delights in it, and finds it satisfactory.

original: catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati, so taṁ assādeti taṁ nikāmeti tena ca vittiṁ āpajjatī”ti.🔽Attheva suttantoti?
analyzed: catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati saḥ tam assādeti tam nikāmeti tena ca vittim āpajjati iti  atthā iva suttanto ti
translated: With the abandoning of pleasure and pain, and with the previous disappearance of joy and grief, he enters upon and abides in the fourth jhāna, which has neither-pain-nor-pleasure and purity of mindfulness due to equanimity’?”
“Yes, venerable sir.”

original: Tena hi samāpanno assādeti, jhānanikanti jhānārammaṇāti.
analyzed: tena hi samāpannaḥ assādeti jhāna nikanti jhāna ārammaṇā ati
translated: “Then you must abandon that assertion and adopt the opposite.”
The discussion is ended.
